css.name: Calderbank-Shor-Steane (CSS) stabilizer code
css.protection:
Detects errors on \(d-1\) qubits, corrects errors on \(\left\lfloor (d-1)/2 \right\rfloor\) qubits.

Using the relation to chain complexes, the number of encoded logical qubits is equal to the dimension of the first \(\mathbb{Z}_2\)-homology of the chain complex, \(H_1(\partial, \mathbb{Z}_2) = \frac{\text{Ker}(\partial_1)}{\text{Im}(\partial_2)}\). The distance of the CSS code is equal to the minimum of the combinatorial (\(d-1\))-systole of the cellulated \(d\)-dimensional manifold and its dual.

features.rate: For a depolarizing channel with probability \(p\), CSS codes allowing for arbitrarily accurate recovery exist with asymptotic rate \(1-2h(p)\), where \(h\) is the binary entropy function \cite{arxiv:quant-ph/0110143}.
transversal_gates: CNOT gates. Self-dual CSS codes admit transversal Clifford gates.
general_gates: LDPC CSS code symmetries called \(XZ\)-dualities allow for fold-transversal gates, i.e., transversal gates followed by qubit permutations \cite{arxiv:2202.06647}.
fault_tolerance: Parallel syndrome extraction for distance-three codes can be done fault-tolerantly using one flag qubit \cite{arXiv:2208.00581}.
code_capacity_threshold: Bounds on code capacity thresholds for various noise models exist in terms of stabilizer generator weights \cite{arxiv:1208.2317,arxiv:1412.6172}.
decoders: Coherent decoders allow for measurement-free error correction \cite{arxiv:2109.00086}. One method is table/multi-control decoding \cite{arXiv:1002.1536}, which scales exponentially with the number of ancillas used in syndrome measurement. Another method, the Ising-based decoder, utilizes the mapping of the effect of the noise to a statistical mechanical model \cite{arxiv:quant-ph/0110143,arXiv:2002.11733} such that the decoding problem maps to preparation of the ground state of an Ising model.

realizations: Entanglement purification protocols related to quantum key distribution (QKD) \cite{arxiv:quant-ph/0003004}.
notes: Using linear programming to solve a set of equations and inequalities on weight distribution of a classical self-orthogonal code \(C=(n, 2^n-k)\) and its dual, one can find a \(C\) such that the \([[n,k,d]]\) CSS code constructed using \(C\) and its dual would have rate and distance close to the Singleton bound \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/9608006}.
Original requirement of \(C_1^\perp \subset C_2\) \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/9512032} has been relaxed to absorb hypergraph product codes.

parents.detail: Stabilizer generators can be expressed as either only \(X\)-type or only \(Z\)-type.

cousins.detail: Construction uses two related binary linear codes.

Pryadko, “Thresholds for Correcting Errors, Erasures, and Faulty Syndrome Measurements in Degenerate Quantum Codes”, Physical Review Letters 115, (2015) arXiv:1412.6172 DOI].

binary_linear.name: Linear binary code
binary_linear.description:
An \((n,2^k,d)\) linear code is denoted as \([n,k]\) or \([n,k,d]\), where \(d\) is the code's distance. Its codewords form a linear subspace, i.e., for any codewords \(x,y\), \(x+y\) is also a codeword. A code that is not linear is called \textit{nonlinear}.

Linear codes can be defined in terms of a \textit{generator matrix} \(G\), whose rows form a basis for the \(k\)-dimensional codespace. Given a message \(x\), the corresponding encoded codeword is \(G^T x\). The generator matrix can be reduced via coordinate permutations to its \textit{standard} or \textit{systematic form} \(G = [I_k~A]\), where \(I_k\) is a \(k\times k\) identity matrix and \(A\) is a \(k \times (n-k)\) binary matrix.
binary_linear.protection:
Distance \(d\) of a linear code is the number of nonzero entries in the (nonzero) codeword with the smallest such number. Corrects any error set for which no two elements of the set add up to a codeword.

Linear codes admit a \textit{parity check matrix} \(H\), whose columns make up a set of \textit{parity checks}, i.e., a maximal linearly independent set of vectors that are in the kernel of \(G\). It follows that
\begin{align}
  G H^{\text{T}} = 0 \mod 2~.
\end{align}

features.rate: A family of linear codes \(C_i = [n_i,k_i,d_i]\) is \textit{asymptotically good} if the asymptotic rate \(\lim_{i\to\infty} k_i/n_i\) and asymptotic distance \(\lim_{i\to\infty} d_i/n_i\) are both positive.
decoders: Decoding an arbitary linear binary code is NP-hard \cite{doi:10.1109/TIT.1978.1055873}.

notes: Tables of bounds and examples of linear codes for various \(n\) and \(k\), extending code tables by A. E. Brouwer \cite{manual:{Andries E. Brouwer, Bounds on linear codes, in: Vera S. Pless and W. Cary Huffman (Eds.), Handbook of Coding Theory, pp. 295-461, Elsevier, 1998.}}, are maintained by M. Grassl at this \href{http://codetables.markus-grassl.de/}{website}.

searchable_text_doc.description:
An \((n,2^k,d)\) linear code is denoted as \([n,k]\) or \([n,k,d]\), where \(d\) is the code's distance. Its codewords form a linear subspace, i.e., for any codewords \(x,y\), \(x+y\) is also a codeword. A code that is not linear is called nonlinear.

Linear codes can be defined in terms of a generator matrix \(G\), whose rows form a basis for the \(k\)-dimensional codespace. Given a message \(x\), the corresponding encoded codeword is \(G^T x\). The generator matrix can be reduced via coordinate permutations to its standard or systematic form \(G = [I_k~A]\), where \(I_k\) is a \(k\times k\) identity matrix and \(A\) is a \(k \times (n-k)\) binary matrix.
searchable_text_doc.protection:
Distance \(d\) of a linear code is the number of nonzero entries in the (nonzero) codeword with the smallest such number. Corrects any error set for which no two elements of the set add up to a codeword.

Linear codes admit a parity check matrix \(H\), whose columns make up a set of parity checks, i.e., a maximal linearly independent set of vectors that are in the kernel of \(G\). It follows that \begin{align}
  G H^{\text{T}} = 0 \mod 2~.
\tag*{(1)}\end{align}

qubits_into_qubits.name: Qubit code
qubits_into_qubits.description: Encodes \(K\)-dimensional Hilbert space into a \(2^n\)-dimensional (i.e., \(n\)-qubit) Hilbert space. Usually denoted as \(((n,K))\) or \(((n,K,d))\), where \(d\) is the code's distance.

searchable_text_doc.name: Qubit code
searchable_text_doc.description: Encodes \(K\)-dimensional Hilbert space into a \(2^n\)-dimensional (i.e., \(n\)-qubit) Hilbert space. Usually denoted as \(((n,K))\) or \(((n,K,d))\), where \(d\) is the code's distance.

stabilizer.name: Stabilizer code
stabilizer.description: An \(((n,2^k,d))\) stabilizer code is denoted as \([[n,k]]\) or \([[n,k,d]]\), where \(d\) is the code's distance. Logical subspace is the joint \(+1\) eigenspace of a set of \(2^{n-k}\) commuting Pauli operators forming the code's stabilizer group. The distance is the minimum weight of a Pauli string that implements a nontrivial logical operation on the code.
stabilizer.protection: Detects errors on up to \(d-1\) qubits, and corrects erasure errors on up to \(d-1\) qubits.

encoders: Dissipative preparation, for which codespace is steady-state space of a Lindbladian \cite{arXiv:1310.1036}.

searchable_text_doc.name: Stabilizer code
searchable_text_doc.description: An \(((n,2^k,d))\) stabilizer code is denoted as \([[n,k]]\) or \([[n,k,d]]\), where \(d\) is the code's distance. Logical subspace is the joint \(+1\) eigenspace of a set of \(2^{n-k}\) commuting Pauli operators forming the code's stabilizer group. The distance is the minimum weight of a Pauli string that implements a nontrivial logical operation on the code.
searchable_text_doc.introduced: [D. Gottesman, “Stabilizer Codes and Quantum Error Correction”, (1997) arXiv:quant-ph/9705052]
searchable_text_doc.protection: Detects errors on up to \(d-1\) qubits, and corrects erasure errors on up to \(d-1\) qubits.
searchable_text_doc.features_encoders: Dissipative preparation, for which codespace is steady-state space of a Lindbladian [J. Dengis, R. König, and F. Pastawski, “An optimal dissipative encoder for the toric code”, New Journal of Physics 16, 013023 (2014) arXiv:1310.1036 DOI].

surface.name: Kitaev's surface code
surface.description: A family of stabilizer codes whose generators are few-body \(X\)-type and \(Z\)-type Pauli strings associated to the stars and plaquettes, respectively, of a tessellation of a two-dimensional surface (with a qubit located at each edge of the tesselation). \textit{Toric code} often either refers to the construction on the two-dimensional torus or is an alternative name for the general construction. The construction on surfaces with boundaries is often called the \textit{planar code} \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/9811052}.
surface.protection: When defined on an \(L\times L\) square tiling of the torus, protects against \(L\) errors. More generally, the code distance is related to the homology of the tessellation \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/0110143}.

general_gates: Clifford gates can be implemented via lattice surgery \cite{arXiv:1111.4022,arXiv:1709.02318} or braiding defects \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/0610082,arXiv:quant-ph/0703143,arXiv:1208.0928,arXiv:1609.04673}.
Non-Clifford gates require magic state distillation \cite{arXiv:1905.06903} or just-in-time decoding \cite{arXiv:1903.11634}.
code_capacity_threshold: \(10.9\%\) with independent \(X/Z\) errors for square tiling \cite{arXiv:0811.0464}.
\(18.9\%\) with depolarizing noise for square tiling \cite{arXiv:1202.1852}.
threshold: \(10.9\%\) with independent \(X/Z\) errors for square tiling \cite{arXiv:0811.0464}.
\(18.9\%\) with depolarizing noise for square tiling \cite{arXiv:1202.1852}.
\(50\%\) with loss errors for square tiling \cite{arXiv:0904.3556}.
\(3.3\%\) with phenomenological noise for square tiling \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/0401101}.
decoders: Minimum weight perfect-matching \cite{arXiv:quant-ph/0110143,doi:10.26421/QIC15.1-2-9}, union-find \cite{arXiv:1709.06218}, renormalization group \cite{doi:10.26421/QIC14.9-10-1,arXiv:1411.3028}, tensor network \cite{arXiv:1405.4883}, Markov chain Monte Carlo \cite{arXiv:1302.2669}, cellular automaton \cite{arXiv:1511.05579}, machine learning \cite{arXiv:1610.04238,arXiv:1802.06441,arXiv:1810.07207}.

notes: Toric code introductions from error-correction perspective by \href{https://boulderschool.yale.edu/2018/boulder-school-2018-lecture-notes}{J. Haah} and condensed-matter perspective by \href{https://boulderschool.yale.edu/2016/boulder-school-2016-lecture-notes}{M. Levin and C. Nayak}.
realizations: Distance-two surface codes have been implemented by Andersen et al. \cite{arXiv:1912.09410}, Erhard et al. \cite{arXiv:2006.03071} and Google Quantum AI \cite{doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03588-y}.

parents.detail: Plaquette and star operators are stabilizer generators.
The surface code is a topological code

searchable_text_doc.name: Kitaev's surface code
searchable_text_doc.description: A family of stabilizer codes whose generators are few-body \(X\)-type and \(Z\)-type Pauli strings associated to the stars and plaquettes, respectively, of a tessellation of a two-dimensional surface (with a qubit located at each edge of the tesselation). Toric code often either refers to the construction on the two-dimensional torus or is an alternative name for the general construction. The construction on surfaces with boundaries is often called the planar code [S. B. Bravyi and A. Yu. Kitaev, “Quantum codes on a lattice with boundary”, (1998) arXiv:quant-ph/9811052].
searchable_text_doc.introduced: [A. Yu. Kitaev, “Quantum Error Correction with Imperfect Gates”, Quantum Communication, Computing, and Measurement 181 (1997) DOI][A. Yu. Kitaev, “Fault-tolerant quantum computation by anyons”, Annals of Physics 303, 2 (2003) arXiv:quant-ph/9707021 DOI]
searchable_text_doc.protection: When defined on an \(L\times L\) square tiling of the torus, protects against \(L\) errors. More generally, the code distance is related to the homology of the tessellation [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.features_encoders:
Unitary [M. Aguado and G. Vidal, “Entanglement Renormalization and Topological Order”, Physical Review Letters 100, (2008) arXiv:0712.0348 DOI][O. Higgott et al., “Optimal local unitary encoding circuits for the surface code”, Quantum 5, 517 (2021) arXiv:2002.00362 DOI][Y.-J. Liu et al., “Methods for Simulating String-Net States and Anyons on a Digital Quantum Computer”, PRX Quantum 3, (2022) arXiv:2110.02020 DOI].
Dissipative [J. Dengis, R. König, and F. Pastawski, “An optimal dissipative encoder for the toric code”, New Journal of Physics 16, 013023 (2014) arXiv:1310.1036 DOI].
Stabilizer measurement-based [J. Łodyga et al., “Simple scheme for encoding and decoding a qubit in unknown state for various topological codes”, Scientific Reports 5, (2015) arXiv:1404.2495 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.features_general_gates:
Clifford gates can be implemented via lattice surgery [D. Horsman et al., “Surface code quantum computing by lattice surgery”, New Journal of Physics 14, 123011 (2012) arXiv:1111.4022 DOI][D. Litinski and F. von Oppen, “Lattice Surgery with a Twist: Simplifying Clifford Gates of Surface Codes”, Quantum 2, 62 (2018) arXiv:1709.02318 DOI] or braiding defects [R. Raussendorf and J. Harrington, “Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation with High Threshold in Two Dimensions”, Physical Review Letters 98, (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0610082 DOI][R. Raussendorf, J. Harrington, and K. Goyal, “Topological fault-tolerance in cluster state quantum computation”, New Journal of Physics 9, 199 (2007) arXiv:quant-ph/0703143 DOI][A. G. Fowler et al., “Surface codes: Towards practical large-scale quantum computation”, Physical Review A 86, (2012) arXiv:1208.0928 DOI][B. J. Brown et al., “Poking Holes and Cutting Corners to Achieve Clifford Gates with the Surface Code”, Physical Review X 7, (2017) arXiv:1609.04673 DOI].
Non-Clifford gates require magic state distillation [D. Litinski, “Magic State Distillation: Not as Costly as You Think”, Quantum 3, 205 (2019) arXiv:1905.06903 DOI] or just-in-time decoding [B. J. Brown, “A fault-tolerant non-Clifford gate for the surface code in two dimensions”, Science Advances 6, (2020) arXiv:1903.11634 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.features_decoders: Minimum weight perfect-matching [E. Dennis et al., “Topological quantum memory”, Journal of Mathematical Physics 43, 4452 (2002) arXiv:quant-ph/0110143 DOI][A. G. Fowler, “Minimum weight perfect matching of fault-tolerant topological quantum error correction in average O(1) parallel time”, Quantum Information and Computation 15, 145 (2015) DOI], union-find [N. Delfosse and N. H. Nickerson, “Almost-linear time decoding algorithm for topological codes”, Quantum 5, 595 (2021) arXiv:1709.06218 DOI], renormalization group [G. Duclos-Cianci and D. Poulin, “Fault-tolerant renormalization group decoder for abelian topological codes”, Quantum Information and Computation 14, 721 (2014) DOI][F. H. E. Watson, H. Anwar, and D. E. Browne, “Fast fault-tolerant decoder for qubit and qudit surface codes”, Physical Review A 92, (2015) arXiv:1411.3028 DOI], tensor network [S. Bravyi, M. Suchara, and A. Vargo, “Efficient algorithms for maximum likelihood decoding in the surface code”, Physical Review A 90, (2014) arXiv:1405.4883 DOI], Markov chain Monte Carlo [A. Hutter, J. R. Wootton, and D. Loss, “Efficient Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm for the surface code”, Physical Review A 89, (2014) arXiv:1302.2669 DOI], cellular automaton [M. Herold et al., “Cellular automaton decoders of topological quantum memories in the fault tolerant setting”, New Journal of Physics 19, 063012 (2017) arXiv:1511.05579 DOI], machine learning [G. Torlai and R. G. Melko, “Neural Decoder for Topological Codes”, Physical Review Letters 119, (2017) arXiv:1610.04238 DOI][C. Chamberland and P. Ronagh, “Deep neural decoders for near term fault-tolerant experiments”, Quantum Science and Technology 3, 044002 (2018) arXiv:1802.06441 DOI][R. Sweke et al., “Reinforcement learning decoders for fault-tolerant quantum computation”, Machine Learning: Science and Technology 2, 025005 (2020) arXiv:1810.07207 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.features_threshold:
\(10.9\%\) with independent \(X/Z\) errors for square tiling [M. Ohzeki, “Locations of multicritical points for spin glasses on regular lattices”, Physical Review E 79, (2009) arXiv:0811.0464 DOI].
\(18.9\%\) with depolarizing noise for square tiling [H. Bombin et al., “Strong Resilience of Topological Codes to Depolarization”, Physical Review X 2, (2012) arXiv:1202.1852 DOI].
\(50\%\) with loss errors for square tiling [T. M. Stace, S. D. Barrett, and A. C. Doherty, “Thresholds for Topological Codes in the Presence of Loss”, Physical Review Letters 102, (2009) arXiv:0904.3556 DOI].
\(3.3\%\) with phenomenological noise for square tiling [T. Ohno et al., “Phase structure of the random-plaquette gauge model: accuracy threshold for a toric quantum memory”, Nuclear Physics B 697, 462 (2004) arXiv:quant-ph/0401101 DOI].
\(0.5-1.1\%\) for various error models [A. M. Stephens, “Fault-tolerant thresholds for quantum error correction with the surface code”, Physical Review A 89, (2014) arXiv:1311.5003 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.features_code_capacity_threshold:
\(10.9\%\) with independent \(X/Z\) errors for square tiling [M. Ohzeki, “Locations of multicritical points for spin glasses on regular lattices”, Physical Review E 79, (2009) arXiv:0811.0464 DOI].
\(18.9\%\) with depolarizing noise for square tiling [H. Bombin et al., “Strong Resilience of Topological Codes to Depolarization”, Physical Review X 2, (2012) arXiv:1202.1852 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.realizations: Distance-two surface codes have been implemented by Andersen et al. [C. K. Andersen et al., “Repeated quantum error detection in a surface code”, Nature Physics 16, 875 (2020) arXiv:1912.09410 DOI], Erhard et al. [A. Erhard et al., “Entangling logical qubits with lattice surgery”, Nature 589, 220 (2021) arXiv:2006.03071 DOI] and Google Quantum AI [“Exponential suppression of bit or phase errors with cyclic error correction”, Nature 595, 383 (2021) DOI].
searchable_text_doc.notes: Toric code introductions from error-correction perspective by J. Haah and condensed-matter perspective by M. Levin and C. Nayak.
searchable_text_doc.relations_parents_detail:
Plaquette and star operators are stabilizer generators.
The surface code is a topological code

Here is the code's description.  It can span multiple, hard-wrapped lines.
It can include citations~\cite{arXiv:1911.00099}.
You can have math like \(a+b\) or \(\int_0^\infty f(x)\,dx\).  You can also
write \(\ket\psi = \sum_k \braket{e_k|\phi}\ket{e_k}\).

The description field can contain multiple paragraphs, like this.  Each
\textbf{paragraph} can contain \emph{formatted text}, including
\href{https://phfaist.com/}{hyperlinks} and direct URLs:
\url{https://arxiv.org/}.  The stabilizers are given in \eqref{eq:stabilizers}.

Have fun\textbf{!!}

Funny Code
Bunny Code
Sunny Puny Tanny Dumby Rambly Code
searchable_text_doc.description:
Here is the code's description. It can span multiple, hard-wrapped lines. It can include citations [V. V. Albert, J. P. Covey, and J. Preskill, “Robust Encoding of a Qubit in a Molecule”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1911.00099 DOI]. You can have math like \(a+b\) or \(\int_0^\infty f(x)\,dx\). You can also write \(\ket\psi = \sum_k \braket{e_k|\phi}\ket{e_k}\).

The description field can contain multiple paragraphs, like this. Each paragraph can contain formatted text, including hyperlinks and direct URLs: arxiv.org. The stabilizers are given in (3).

Have fun!!

Check this citation that doesn't resolve with crossref [A. M. Kubica, The ABCs of the Color Code: A Study of Topological Quantum Codes as Toy Models for Fault-Tolerant Quantum Computation and Quantum Phases Of Matter, California Institute of Technology, 2018 DOI].
searchable_text_doc.introduced: [V. V. Albert, J. P. Covey, and J. Preskill, “Robust Encoding of a Qubit in a Molecule”, Physical Review X 10, (2020) arXiv:1911.00099 DOI]
searchable_text_doc.protection:
Detects errors on \(d-1\) qubits, corrects errors on \(\left\lfloor (d-1)/2
\right\rfloor\) qubits.

[figure]
[/fig/fig-testfigure.ttrj.png]

Figure I: Here's a test figure.


We'll try out some tables with fictitious “Exponents”, too.

[figure]
[/fig/fig-testtable.nz3z.svg]

Table I: A shiny table.


[figure]
[/fig/fig-testfigure2.frk5.png]

Figure II: Another test for a figure. Let's see what happens when we have a really long caption that can span multiple lines like this, without it being necessarily informative. After all, this article is really only a dummy example meant to test different features of the generator of our pretty site errorcorrectionzoo.org.


And another figure, this time in jpeg format!

[figure]
[/fig/fig-scenery.btyd.jpeg]

Figure III: Isn't southern Italy simply stunning?


Another flashy figure:

[figure]
[/fig/fig-flashyfigure.s59q.svg]

Figure IV: Pretty flashy.


We can use definition environments, too:

Knill-Laflamme conditions: In a finite-dimensional Hilbert space, there are necessary and sufficient conditions for a code to successfully correct a set of errors. These are called the Knill-Laflamme conditions [E. Knill, R. Laflamme, and L. Viola, “Theory of Quantum Error Correction for General Noise”, Physical Review Letters 84, 2525 (2000) arXiv:quant-ph/9604034 DOI][J. Preskill. Lecture notes on Quantum Computation. (1997–2020) URL][M. A. Nielsen and I. L. Chuang, Quantum Computation and Quantum Information (Cambridge University Press, 2012) DOI; Thm. 10.1]. A code defined by a partial isometry \(U\) with code space projector \(\Pi = U U^\dagger\) can correct a set of errors \(\{ E_j \}\) if and only if \begin{align}
    \Pi E_i^\dagger E_j \Pi = c_{ij}\, \Pi\qquad\text{for all \(i,j\),}
  \tag*{(1)}\end{align} where \(c_{ij}\) can be arbitrary numbers.
searchable_text_doc.notes:
A first note goes here, which includes a cross-reference to the CSS code.

Multiple paragraphs here.a Here's also a reference to Figure I and Figure V.
Another thing we should try out is what happens when we have really, really, really long equations. \begin{align}
  F\bigl(\psi, -i[H,\psi]\bigr)
  \geq
  F\bigl(\mathcal{N}(\psi), \mathcal{N}(-i[H,\psi])\bigr)
  \geq
  F\bigl(\psi, -i[H,\psi]\bigr)
  - 8\epsilon \bigl\Vert{-i[H,\psi]}\bigr\Vert_1\bigl\Vert{-i[H,\psi]}\bigr\Vert_\infty\ .
\tag*{(2)}\end{align} 
Test citation to book [M. A. Nielsen and I. L. Chuang, Quantum Computation and Quantum Information (Cambridge University Press, 2012) DOI]. Test citation to arXiv entry with incomplete DOI (issue #43) [B. Criger and B. Terhal, “Noise thresholds for the [4,2,2]-concatenated toric code”, Quantum Information and Computation 16, 1261 (2016) arXiv:1604.04062 DOI]. Test citing a preset: [J. Preskill. Lecture notes on Quantum Computation. (1997–2020) URL]. Test citing a preset with citation note: [J. Preskill. Lecture notes on Quantum Computation. (1997–2020) URL; Chap. 6]. 
By the way, you can |\input %verbatim$ text&*~like
this.\end{booh} using the \begin{vertatimtext} ... \end {verbatimtext}
environment|!

A bug can occur if a paper on the arXiv has a ‘%’ sign in its title:[D. K. Tuckett et al., “Fault-Tolerant Thresholds for the Surface Code in Excess of 5% Under Biased Noise”, Physical Review Letters 124, (2020) arXiv:1907.02554 DOI]

Also let's make sure that pure arXiv citations work: [H. Barnum and E. Knill, “Reversing quantum dynamics with near-optimal quantum and classical fidelity”, (2000) arXiv:quant-ph/0004088] (which also tests citations to old-style arxiv ID's).
Here's a reference to the CSS-to-homology correspondence, by the way. 
A second note goes here. This one contains a display equation: \begin{align}
  S_1 &= I\,Z\,X\,X\,Z\ ;  \nonumber\\
  S_2, \ldots, S_4 &= \text{cyclical permutations of \(S_1\)}\ .
  \label{eq:stabilizers}
\tag*{(3)}\end{align} Note that the last cyclical permutation of \(S_1\) is not included, as it is given by \(S_1S_2S_3S_4\).

Yeah! Also again the reference Knill-Laflamme conditions

Use of the gather environment: \begin{gather}
   A = B + C\tag*{(4)}\\
   x = y + z
\tag*{(5)}\end{gather}

Use of the split environment inside align: \begin{align}
  \begin{split}
    A &= B + C\\
    x &= y + z
  \end{split}
\tag*{(6)}\end{align}

Test a manual citation [A. Smith et al., Textbook of fancy stuff, Taylor & Francis, 1999].
Figures don't need to have numbers & captions (but then you can't reference them):

[figure]
[/fig/fig-testfigure.ttrj.png]


Or you can simply have the figure number:

[figure]
[/fig/fig-testfigure.ttrj.png]

Figure V


Or only a caption on its own:

[figure]
[/fig/fig-testfigure.ttrj.png]

Figure: This figure has no number, and I can't refer to it with a ref command.

code_id._description: An internal identifier for the code.  It must be unique across all codes on the error correction zoo.

name._description: The name of the code.  It is listed in multiple places, so don't make it too long.

short_name._description: (Optional.) A short name in case the 'name' field is long.  The short name is used in places where space is precious, such as in the navigation links in the header bar.  If no 'short_name' is provided, the 'name' field is used in those places instead.

alternative_names._description: Alternative name(s) under which this code is known.

description._description: Describe code subspace as best as you can here.  Anything applicable to a larger parent set of codes (see below) should go in that entry instead of here.

introduced._description: First reference with the code (optional).  This field should be a single ‘\cite{}’ command with the appropriate reference(s).  Recall that you can cite multiple references with a single ‘\cite’ command, separating keys with commas.

_meta._description: The _meta field contains additional meta-information data about the error correction zoo entry itself.  We store among others the list of people who have contributed to this particular entry.

changelog._description:
The list of significant edits to this entry, in chronological order. Edits are included only if the contribution is substantial; fixing typos and formatting tweaks are not considered substantial contributions.
Make sure you add your own name here if you're editing this entry!

date._description: (Approximate) date of the modification, in the format YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM

notes._description: Any additional notes that are worty to store with regards to this particular edit.  Usually you should leave this blank.

stub._description: Set to true if this entry is a stub and is intended to be completed at a later time.

items._description: A collection of predicates used to specify which codes should be included in a code list page.  Predicates specified together as different keys in this object combine with "AND" logic, i.e., all the predicate keys given by the user in this object instance need to be satisfied for a code to be included in the codes collected by this predicate collection.

property._description: Require a code to have the property `name` set to the value `value` (comparison with JS strict equality "===").

manual_code_list._description: Only include codes that are explicitly specified in this list of code_ids.

exclude._description: Include codes except those that are explicitly specified in this list of code_ids.

property_set._description: Only include codes that have the given property name set to a non-null/non-undefined value.

any_property_set._description: Only include codes that have one or more of the given property names set to a non-null/non-undefined value.

all_property_set._description: Only include codes that have all of the given property names set to a non-null/non-undefined value.

not_property_set._description: Only include codes that do not have the given property name set to a non-null/non-undefined value.

not_any_property_set._description: Only include codes that do not have one or more of the given property names set to a non-null/non-undefined value.

not_all_property_set._description: Only include codes that do not have all of the given property names set to a non-null/non-undefined value.

domain._description: Only include codes that are descendants of the domain with the given domain_id.

any_domain._description: Only include codes that are descendants of any of the domains corresponding to the given domain_id's.

all_domain._description: Only include codes that are descendants of all of the domains corresponding to the given domain_id's.

not_domain._description: Only include codes that are not descendants of the domain corresponding to the given domain_id.

not_any_domain._description: Only include codes that are not descendants of any of the domains corresponding to the given domain_id's.

not_all_domain._description: Only include codes that are not descendants of all the domains corresponding to the given domain_id's.

descendant_of._description: Only include codes that are descendants of the code corresponding to the given code_id.

any_descendant_of._description: Only include codes that are descendants of any of the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

all_descendant_of._description: Only include codes that are descendants of all the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

not_descendant_of._description: Only include codes that are not descendants of the code corresponding to the given code_id.

not_any_descendant_of._description: Only include codes that are not descendants of any of the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

not_all_descendant_of._description: Only include codes that are not descendants of all the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

cousin_of._description: Only include codes that are direct cousins of the code corresponding to the given code_id.

any_cousin_of._description: Only include codes that are direct cousins of any of the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

all_cousin_of._description: Only include codes that are direct cousins of all the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

not_cousin_of._description: Only include codes that are not direct cousins of the code corresponding to the given code_id.

not_any_cousin_of._description: Only include codes that are not direct cousins of any of the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

not_all_cousin_of._description: Only include codes that are not direct cousins of all of the codes corresponding to the given code_id's.

codes._description: Specify the logic that determines which codes are included in this list.  The "codes: select:" object value is an array of predicate collections.  Within each predicate collection, each predicate must match (AND logic within each predicate collection); codes are collected from the different predicate collections in the array and combined together (OR logic between predicate collections).

user_id._description: A unique, internal identifier for the user.

name._description: The user's full name, as it should be displayed.

zooteam._description: Zoo team indicates membership to a particular "team" (Core, Veterinarians, Code Contributors).  Leave blank for code contributors.

zoorole._description: Zoo role is applicable to core team members, otherwise omit field.

gscholaruser._description: The user's Google scholar profile ID

avatarurl._description: A link to a profile picture (image) for this user
